meta.title: Skeletal muscle relaxants: Neuromuscular blocking agents

content:
Introduction

Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) are medications that cause complete skeletal muscle paralysis by targeting nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.  NMBAs are classified as either depolarizing or nondepolarizing based on their mechanism of action.  These medications are used most often to facilitate intubation, provide muscle relaxation during surgery, or enable prolonged mechanical ventilation.

Neuromuscular junction physiology



The neuromuscular junction consists of the presynaptic motor neuron terminal, synaptic cleft, and postsynaptic motor endplate, which contains nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.  When an action potential reaches the presynaptic motor neuron terminal, it triggers the release of acetylcholine (ACh) into the synaptic cleft.  Acetylcholine then binds to the postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on the motor endplate, leading to the depolarization of the myocyte membrane and causing muscle contraction (

).

Indications



NMBAs induce skeletal muscle paralysis by acting at the neuromuscular junction.  They do not affect smooth or cardiac muscle, but they do paralyze respiratory muscles (eg, diaphragm); therefore, patients require mechanical ventilation.  Because NMBAs lack sedative or analgesic effects, adequate sedation and pain control are crucial for preventing awareness and distress during paralysis.  Common indications include:



  • Endotracheal intubation:  Paralysis of the vocal cords and diaphragm improves intubating conditions, increases success rates, and reduces the risk for vomiting and aspiration during procedures.
  • Surgery:  Muscle relaxation is especially beneficial during laparoscopic or robotic procedures, abdominal or thoracic surgeries, and intricate microsurgical dissections in which complete immobility of the patient is required.
  • Mechanical ventilation:  NMBAs prevent coughing and patientâ€“ventilator asynchrony.  By allowing the ventilator to perform all respiratory work, these medications help reduce metabolic demand and oxygen consumption in severely hypoxemic, critically ill patients (eg, acute respiratory distress syndrome).
  • Therapeutic hypothermia:  Neuromuscular blockade is used to prevent shivering during therapeutic hypothermia following cardiac arrest.  Shivering not only generates heat and opposes cooling efforts, but also raises metabolic demand, undermining the goals of hypothermia.

Mechanism of action



NMBAs are classified as either depolarizing or nondepolarizing based on their specific mechanism of action.

Depolarizing agents



Depolarizing agents (eg, succinylcholine) act as strong nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonists at the neuromuscular junction.  Succinylcholine binds the receptor and causes sustained depolarization of the muscle membrane.  This renders the muscle fiber unable to repolarize, resulting in transient fasciculations (muscle contractions) followed by flaccid paralysis.  This effect occurs in 2 phases:



  • Phase I (prolonged depolarization):  Sustained depolarization of the motor endplate keeps voltage-gated sodium channels in their inactivated state, preventing the generation of further action potentials and leading to flaccid paralysis of the muscle.
  • Phase II (repolarization with desensitization):  The motor endplate gradually repolarizes with continued administration of succinylcholine, but the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors become desensitized and less responsive.

Nondepolarizing agents



Nondepolarizing agents (eg, rocuronium, vecuronium) act as competitive nicotinic acetylcholine receptor antagonists at the neuromuscular junction.  They bind to the postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (without activating them) and block acetylcholine from binding.  This prevents depolarization and muscle contraction.

Pharmacokinetics and drug selection



NMBAs are typically administered via the intravenous route.  Depending on the desired duration of action, the medication can be given as a bolus (eg, rapid sequence intubation) or an infusion (eg, prolonged mechanical ventilation).  Dosing calculations are based on ideal (not actual) body weight to avoid overdose or prolonged effects.

Depolarizing agents

Succinylcholine



  • The only clinically available depolarizing agent.


  • Most often used for rapid sequence intubation (ie, rapid sequence administration of an induction agent and NMBA).
  • Onset/duration of action:  Rapid onset (30-60 sec), ultrashort duration of action (6 min).
  • Metabolism:  Rapidly metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase.
  • Reversal agents:  None.
  • Adverse effects (

    ):
    • Hyperkalemia:  Activation of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors causes sodium influx and potassium efflux.  Exaggerated hyperkalemia and life-threatening arrhythmias can occur in patients with crush or burn injuries, denervating injuries or diseases (eg, quadriplegia, Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome), and myopathies.  These pathologic states cause upregulation of muscle nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and/or rhabdomyolysis, which can result in the release of large amounts of potassium when succinylcholine is administered.
    • Malignant hyperthermia (in genetically predisposed individuals):  This occurs, particularly with coadministration of halothane.
  • Contraindications:
    • Burns (after 24-48 hr), crush injuries, spinal cord injuries.
    • Neuromuscular diseases (eg, muscular dystrophy, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome, multiple sclerosis).
    • Elevated potassium levels (eg, chronic kidney disease).
    • History of malignant hyperthermia.
    • Plasma pseudocholinesterase deficiency:  An autosomal recessive disorder that impairs the metabolism of succinylcholine and prolongs its paralytic effects.

Nondepolarizing agents

Rocuronium



  • The most common alternative to succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation.
  • Onset/duration of action:  Rapid onset (1-2 min), intermediate duration of action (30-90 min).
  • Metabolism:  Mostly hepatic (biliary) metabolism/elimination, small amount is excreted renally.
  • Reversal agents:
    • Sugammadex (first-line):  Binds rocuronium with high affinity and renders it incapable of blocking the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
    • Anticholinesterase medications (eg, neostigmine, edrophonium):  Increase the amount of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, enabling them to competitively bind to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and restore nerve transmission and muscle contraction.  Must be given with atropine and glycopyrrolate to prevent muscarinic adverse effects (eg, bradycardia, salivation).
  • Adverse effects:  Prolonged paralysis with hepatic impairment.
  • Contraindications:  None, but rocuronium should be used cautiously in patients with hepatic failure.

Vecuronium



  • Onset/duration of action:  Intermediate onset (3-4 min), intermediate duration of action (25-50 min).
  • Metabolism:  Hepatic and renal excretion.
  • Reversal agents:  Sugammadex and anticholinesterase medications.
  • Adverse effects:  Can accumulate in patients with renal and hepatic dysfunction and cause vagal block (eg, tachycardia).
  • Contraindications:  None, but vecuronium should be used cautiously in patients with renal and hepatic failure.

Atracurium



  • Onset/duration of action:  Intermediate onset (3-6 min), intermediate duration of action (20-60 min).
  • Metabolism:  Hofmann elimination (spontaneous degradation in the plasma, independent of renal and hepatic function).
  • Reversal agents:  Anticholinesterase drugs (sugammadex is not effective).
  • Adverse effects:  Releases histamine and may induce flushing, bronchoconstriction, and decreased blood pressure.
  • Contraindications:  Hemodynamic instability.

Additional considerations



Several medications can potentiate the effects of NMBAs, leading to toxicity or prolonged paralytic effects.  These include inhaled anesthetics, antibiotics (eg, polymyxins, aminoglycosides, vancomycin), calcium channel blockers, lithium, and procainamide.  In addition, electrolyte abnormalities (eg, hypokalemia, hypermagnesemia), hypothermia, and metabolic acidosis can also increase the paralytic effects.



Patients with myasthenia gravis are extremely sensitive to nondepolarizing agents.  Because they have a lower number of functioning nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (due to destruction by autoantibodies), very small doses can induce profound paralysis.  Conversely, patients with myasthenia gravis are often resistant to depolarizing agents.  The reduced number of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors tends to inhibit endplate depolarization, and patients require extremely large doses to induce muscle relaxation.

Assessment of paralytic effect



Train-of-four (TOF) stimulation is used during anesthesia to assess the degree of paralysis induced by NMBAs (

figure 2
).  A peripheral nerve is stimulated 4 times in quick succession, and the muscular response is recorded.  The height of each bar represents the strength of each twitch; higher bars indicate the activation of increasing numbers of individual muscle fibers.



Nondepolarizing agents create a progressive reduction in each of the 4 responses (fading pattern) because competitive inhibition of postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors prevents some of these fibers from activating, decreasing the strength of the twitch with each stimulus.



In contrast, depolarizing agents initially prevent repolarization of the motor endplate and show equal reduction in all 4 twitches (phase I blockade).  Persistent exposure to succinylcholine results in the eventual transition to phase II blockade as the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors become desensitized (ie, functionally similar to nondepolarizing blockade).

Summary



Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) induce skeletal muscle paralysis by interfering with neuromuscular transmission at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on the motor endplate.  They are classified as either depolarizing or nondepolarizing based on their mechanism of action.  Depolarizing agents mimic acetylcholine and cause persistent depolarization of the muscle membrane, whereas nondepolarizing agents competitively block nicotinic acetylcholine receptors without activating them.  These medications are commonly used to facilitate endotracheal intubation and provide muscle relaxation during surgery or mechanical ventilation.
